name: Glutamine
summary: Glutamine is a conditionally essential amino acid that supports gut health, immune function, and may play a role in stress response and mental health.
description: Glutamine is the most abundant amino acid in the body and serves as a critical fuel source for rapidly dividing cells, including those in the immune system and the gastrointestinal tract. It is also a precursor for neurotransmitters such as glutamate and GABA, which are essential for brain function and mood regulation. While commonly used in sports nutrition and recovery, glutamine supplementation has also been investigated for its role in reducing stress-related gut permeability, supporting immune health, and aiding in mood stabilization. Evidence in psychiatric applications remains limited and largely experimental.

metadata.natural_source: Protein-rich foods such as meat, fish, eggs, dairy, legumes
metadata.fda_status: Dietary supplement (not FDA-approved for medical indications)

primary_indications: Support of gut health and integrity
off_label_uses: Adjunctive support in stress-related gut dysfunction
Supportive use in alcohol withdrawal or cravings (limited evidence)
contraindications: History of seizures (due to potential effects on glutamate balance)

items: Supports intestinal barrier function and gut health
Promotes immune system function during stress
Potential role in reducing stress-related symptoms

sections.text: Glutamine acts as a major fuel source for enterocytes and immune cells, helping maintain gut barrier integrity and immune resilience. It is also a biochemical precursor for glutamate and GABA, neurotransmitters involved in excitation and inhibition in the brain, which may explain potential effects on mood and stress regulation.

adult.note: Athletes may use higher doses (up to 30 g/day) short-term under supervision.

sections.pediatric: Not routinely recommended outside clinical use.

sections.text: Gut and immune benefits may occur within days to weeks; effects on mood and stress remain less well-established.

other: High doses may alter neurotransmitter balance.
Use with caution in individuals with liver disease or seizure disorders.

items.risk: May alter effectiveness in some regimens

sections.pregnancy: Limited safety data; use only under supervision
sections.geriatrics: Generally well tolerated; monitor renal and hepatic function if high-dose

sections.text: No tapering required; may discontinue without withdrawal effects.

items: Most abundant amino acid in circulation; becomes 'conditionally essential' during stress or illness.
Some pilot studies suggest reduced alcohol or sugar cravings, but evidence is limited.
Primarily used in sports medicine and gut health rather than psychiatry.
